page.title: 01BUSBY AND AREA:INTRODUCTION
page.content: There are three settlements in the area:Busby(population 4036), Thorntonhall(287)and Waterfoot(1309) The main land use is{AGRICULTURE}on good quality land.The farming is mainly livestock(mostly dairy cattle) and some arable.The average size of a farm is 40-60 hectares.The land is gently undulating and the most significant feature is the White Cart Water,a tributary of the River Clyde. The area around Busby is called Cartvale,meaning 'valley of the Cart'. Busby was once a village but is now a {SUBURB}of Glasgow,10 kilometres south -east of Glasgow city centre.The agricultural area is{GREEN BELT} separating Glasgow's suburbs from the New Town of East Kilbride(4kilometres south-east of Busby).Waterfoot and Thorntonhall are commuter villages with few services and no industry.
